Official_Water_Body_Name: North Fork Mad River Hydrologic Area
Advisory_Detail_Description: Observations at this site include confirmation of harmful algal bloom that  forms potential toxic algal mats that grow attached to cobble, sand, and plants on the bottom of the waterway. The water can appear clear when algal mats are attached to the bottom. These mats can dislodge and float downstream or strand on the shoreline, children and dogs should avoid touching mat material.

AdvisoryDetail: Advisory based on visual and toxins
Advisory_Detail_Description: Advisory based on presence of harmful algal bloom and water testing that detected cyanotoxins.

Observations at this site include confirmation of harmful algal bloom that  forms potential toxic algal mats that grow attached to cobble, sand, and plants on the bottom of the waterway. The water can appear clear when algal mats are attached to the bottom. These mats can dislodge and float downstream or strand on the shoreline, children and dogs should avoid touching mat material.

AdvisoryDetail: Advisory based on visual and toxins; Bottom/benthic bloom observed
Advisory_Detail_Description: Advisory based on presence of harmful algal bloom and water testing that detected cyanotoxins.  Observations at this site include confirmation of harmful algal bloom that  forms potential toxic algal mats that grow attached to cobble, sand, and plants on the bottom of the waterway. The water can appear clear when algal mats are attached to the bottom. These mats can dislodge and float downstream or strand on the shoreline, children and dogs should avoid touching mat material.

Landmark: at Black Miners Bar Boat Dock
Advisory_Detail_Description: Observations at this site include confirmation of harmful algal bloom that  forms potential toxic algal mats that grow attached to cobble, sand, and plants on the bottom of the waterway. The water can appear clear when algal mats are attached to the bottom. These mats can dislodge and float downstream or strand on the shoreline, children and dogs should avoid touching mat material.

Reported_Management_Organizations:
Long Beach Parks Maintenance Department and Aquatechnex, a private contractor, are responsible for water quality in these ponds. However, the City of Long Beach failed to pay Aquatechnex for 8 months so monitoring was not done for a very long time. Ponds have been allowed to stagnate due to water beeing turned off for months. Recommendations for aerators, etc. by Aquatechnex have been ignored.
Today I learned cyanobacteria has been found. Will these ponds be posted?

AdvisoryDetail: Lake-wide advisory; Marine bloom present (red tide)
Advisory_Detail_Description: Advisory applies to the full extent of the lake or reservoir (lake-wide advisory) and is not to limited the location symbolized by this report.  Marine bloom or “red tide” reported in this area. Red tides appear reddish-brown color and can cause marine animal impacts, particularly for fish. CA Water Boards agency recommends people and pets avoid contact with the water during times of any dense blooms or discoloration in the water. People exposed to marine algae blooms via water contact may experience irritation of the eyes, skin, or respiratory system. Report any illnesses of human or animals (domestic and wild) to https://tinyurl.com/HABReport1. More information about marine harmful algal blooms is available on Dept. of Public Health’s Marine Biotoxin Monitoring Program webpage at: https://tinyurl.com/5e8uc9k4.

AdvisoryDetail: Advisory based on visual and toxins; Bottom/benthic bloom observed
Advisory_Detail_Description: Advisory based on presence of harmful algal bloom and water testing that detected cyanotoxins.  Observations at this site include confirmation of harmful algal bloom that  forms potential toxic algal mats that grow attached to cobble, sand, and plants on the bottom of the waterway. The water can appear clear when algal mats are attached to the bottom. These mats can dislodge and float downstream or strand on the shoreline, children and dogs should avoid touching mat material.

AdvisoryDetail: Advisory based on visual and toxins; Floating/planktonic bloom observed
Advisory_Detail_Description: Advisory based on presence of harmful algal bloom and water testing that detected cyanotoxins.  Observations at this site include confirmation of harmful algal bloom that forms floating/planktonic blooms. Children and dogs should avoid skin contact with bloom material that may appear as discolored water, milky water, with a surface sheen (like spilled paint), or scum.
Updates to this report are provided by a routine water monitoring program conducting site visits at this waterway, refer to Organization field above for more information.
Water testing of samples did not detect presence of harmful algal bloom produced by cyanobacteria.

Reported_Management_Organizations: R2 was contacted by San Mateo County Parks and Bay Keeper about this bloom because they wanted help testing it. R2 recommended they reach out to Vanessa at CDPH. San Mateo county is posting the caution planktonic HAB sign in response to this observation. Bay Keeper reported ~25 dead striped bass and a white sturgeon in the area that appeared to be within the bloom.
Advisory_Detail_Description: Marine bloom or “red tide” reported in this area. Red tides appear reddish-brown color and can cause marine animal impacts, particularly for fish. CA Water Boards agency recommends people and pets avoid contact with the water during times of any dense blooms or discoloration in the water. People exposed to marine algae blooms via water contact may experience irritation of the eyes, skin, or respiratory system. Report any illnesses of human or animals (domestic and wild) to https://tinyurl.com/HABReport1. More information about marine harmful algal blooms is available on Dept. of Public Health’s Marine Biotoxin Monitoring Program webpage at: https://tinyurl.com/5e8uc9k4.

AdvisoryDetail: Advisory based on visual and toxins; Bottom/benthic bloom observed
Advisory_Detail_Description: Advisory based on presence of harmful algal bloom and water testing that detected cyanotoxins.  Observations at this site include confirmation of harmful algal bloom that  forms potential toxic algal mats that grow attached to cobble, sand, and plants on the bottom of the waterway. The water can appear clear when algal mats are attached to the bottom. These mats can dislodge and float downstream or strand on the shoreline, children and dogs should avoid touching mat material.

AdvisoryDetail: Advisory based on visual and toxins; Bottom/benthic bloom observed; Floating/planktonic bloom observed
Advisory_Detail_Description: Advisory based on presence of harmful algal bloom and water testing that detected cyanotoxins.  Observations at this site include confirmation of harmful algal bloom that  forms potential toxic algal mats that grow attached to cobble, sand, and plants on the bottom of the waterway. The water can appear clear when algal mats are attached to the bottom. These mats can dislodge and float downstream or strand on the shoreline, children and dogs should avoid touching mat material. AdvisoryDetail: Marine bloom suspected (red tide); Under investigation
Advisory_Detail_Description: Marine bloom or “red tide” are suspected in this area. Red tides appear reddish-brown color and can cause marine animal impacts, particularly for fish. Until water monitoring results are provided to confirm presence of red tide in this area, we recommend people and pets avoid contact with the water during times of any water discoloration or dense blooms in the water. People exposed to marine algae blooms via water contact may experience irritation of the eyes, skin, or respiratory system.   This report is under investigation.

Water_Body_Use: Camping; Contact recreation; Dog walking; Drinking; Fishing; Irrigation; No water recreation; Non-Contact recreation; Other
Advisory_Detail_Description: Advisory is based on visual monitoring for indicators of harmful algal bloom and trigger public health posting of “caution” advisory level.

Marine bloom or “red tide” are suspected in this area. Red tides appear reddish-brown color and can cause marine animal impacts, particularly for fish. Until water monitoring results are provided to confirm presence of red tide in this area, we recommend people and pets avoid contact with the water during times of any water discoloration or dense blooms in the water. People exposed to marine algae blooms via water contact may experience irritation of the eyes, skin, or respiratory system.

Marine bloom or “red tide” reported in this area. Red tides appear reddish-brown color and can cause marine animal impacts, particularly for fish. CA Water Boards agency recommends people and pets avoid contact with the water during times of any dense blooms or discoloration in the water. People exposed to marine algae blooms via water contact may experience irritation of the eyes, skin, or respiratory system. Report any illnesses of human or animals (domestic and wild) to https://tinyurl.com/HABReport1. More information about marine harmful algal blooms is available on Dept. of Public Health’s Marine Biotoxin Monitoring Program webpage at: https://tinyurl.com/5e8uc9k4.

Reported_Management_Organizations: City of Clearlake will not treat the water, we pay a lot to live on the lake and we can’t even use the lake. It’s really bad right now.
Originally reported by Taylor Woodruff, Lake County to CDFW Mortality report

Out of 15 people who spent the weekend at a lake cabin on dates 7/12-7/14, 12 had what appeared to be "bug bites" that morphed into welts and rashes and in one case a severe bacterial infection requiring 2 ABx. Those who had no bites also had not swam in the water. Given such reactions, I hope the water can be tested and signs or communications to the community if there is harmful microbes in water.
Karen entered this case, originally filed to CDFW mortality report. Photos were included but I don't have access to that system. Will have to ask from the separately

Bloom_Texture: Floating mats; Green discoloration; Spilled paint; Surface scum
Reported_Management_Organizations:
this pond is part of Sacramento City Parks and they have a pond contractor -Solitude. This pond has been over dosed with 
McKinley pond is 1.05 acre minus .09 for island=.96 acre water
The products use directions say: 
Blue Lagoon SS - One quart (32oz)/surface acre treats up to 6 feet deep 
Sweet Water Black dye - One quart (32oz)/surface acre treats up to 6 feet deep
On the following was put in the pond:
Apr. 22: Sweet Water Black dye: 16 qts. (512oz), Blue Lagoon SS: 16 qts. (512oz)
May 6: Sweet Water Black dye: 4 qts. (128oz), Blue Lagoon SS 8 qts. (256 oz)
until 10 days ago all hatchling ducklings have died in 24hr of entering pond and 1 duck died 6/20 from toxicity but not determined the agent. It is with F&W.

Longitude above would not accept all the number with a - sign - It is -121.462770

Advisory_Detail_Description: Marine bloom or “red tide” are suspected in this area. Red tides appear reddish-brown color and can cause marine animal impacts, particularly for fish. Until water monitoring results are provided to confirm presence of red tide in this area, we recommend people and pets avoid contact with the water during times of any water discoloration or dense blooms in the water. People exposed to marine algae blooms via water contact may experience irritation of the eyes, skin, or respiratory system.

Marine bloom or “red tide” reported in this area. Red tides appear reddish-brown color and can cause marine animal impacts, particularly for fish. CA Water Boards agency recommends people and pets avoid contact with the water during times of any dense blooms or discoloration in the water. People exposed to marine algae blooms via water contact may experience irritation of the eyes, skin, or respiratory system. Report any illnesses of human or animals (domestic and wild) to https://tinyurl.com/HABReport1. More information about marine harmful algal blooms is available on Dept. of Public Health’s Marine Biotoxin Monitoring Program webpage at: https://tinyurl.com/5e8uc9k4.

Marine bloom or “red tide” are suspected in this area. Red tides appear reddish-brown color and can cause marine animal impacts, particularly for fish. Until water monitoring results are provided to confirm presence of red tide in this area, we recommend people and pets avoid contact with the water during times of any water discoloration or dense blooms in the water. People exposed to marine algae blooms via water contact may experience irritation of the eyes, skin, or respiratory system.

CA Water Boards agency recommends people and pets avoid contact with the water during times of any dense blooms or discoloration in the water. Report any illnesses of human or animals (domestic and wild) to https://tinyurl.com/HABReport1. More information about marine harmful algal blooms is available on Dept. of Public Health’s Marine Biotoxin Monitoring Program webpage at: https://tinyurl.com/5e8uc9k4.  This report is under investigation.

Landmark: Midpeninsula Open Space District Skyline Field Office
Bloom_Size: between a tennis court and a sedan
Reported_Management_Organizations: This pond lies within the District's Skyline Ridge Open Space Preserve and is a non-contact recreation waterbody. District staff collected surface water and floating mat grab samples and submitted them to Bend Genetics for toxin analysis. Results of the surface water sample show non-detection. Results of the floating mat show presence of Lyngbya sp. with 0.16 ug/L anatoxin-a, 0.34 ug/L microsystin, and 0.47 ug/L saxitoxin. Cyclindrospermopsin was not detected. The District is ready to post Cuation-level signs for planktonic and benthic mats at the pond.

Advisory_Detail_Description: Observations at this site include confirmation of harmful algal bloom that  forms potential toxic algal mats that grow attached to cobble, sand, and plants on the bottom of the waterway. The water can appear clear when algal mats are attached to the bottom. These mats can dislodge and float downstream or strand on the shoreline, children and dogs should avoid touching mat material.

Marine bloom or “red tide” reported in this area. Red tides appear reddish-brown color and can cause marine animal impacts, particularly for fish. CA Water Boards agency recommends people and pets avoid contact with the water during times of any dense blooms or discoloration in the water. People exposed to marine algae blooms via water contact may experience irritation of the eyes, skin, or respiratory system. Report any illnesses of human or animals (domestic and wild) to https://tinyurl.com/HABReport1. More information about marine harmful algal blooms is available on Dept. of Public Health’s Marine Biotoxin Monitoring Program webpage at: https://tinyurl.com/5e8uc9k4.
